name: Two-year data detail impact of Evrysdi in SMA
introduction: Baselâs Roche has announced new exploratory two-year data from the SUNFISH study of Evrysdi (risdiplam) in spinal muscular atrophy (SMA).
content:
Basel’s Roche (ROG: SIX) has announced new exploratory two-year data from the SUNFISH study of Evrysdi (risdiplam) in spinal muscular atrophy (SMA).

The Swiss cancer giant is testing the SMN2 splicing modifier as an option for people with Type 2 or non-ambulant Type 3 SMA.

The data suggests that gains in motor function after the first year are sustained for another 12 months, across primary and secondary endpoint measures.

These results add to recently published data from the FIREFISH trial, which showed that treatment with Evrysdi almost doubled levels of the SMN protein for the high-dose group.

Details from the SUNFISH study will be presented at the 2021 Muscular Dystrophy Association (MDA) Virtual Clinical & Scientific Conference.

More choice in SMA

Marketed in the USA by Roche subsidiary Genentech, Evrysdi is the first at-home, orally administered treatment for SMA in adults and children over the age of two.

The treatment, which has been developed in collaboration with PTC Therapeutics (Nasdaq: PTCT) and the SMA Foundation, is expected to provide stiff competition for other options with a less patient-friendly mode of administration.

Rivals include Biogen’s (Nasdaq: BIIB) Spinraza (nusinersen) and Novartis’ (NOVN: V) Zolgensma (onasemnogene abeparvovec).

First approved in 2020, the therapy took in 55 million Swiss francs ($59 million) sales last year. Analysts have forecast peak sales potential of up to $2 billion.

Commenting on the most recent data, principal investigator Eugenio Mercuri said: “These results build on the one-year findings from the SUNFISH trial and importantly show the durability of improvement or stabilization of motor function through two years of treatment.”

He added: “In addition, with no new safety signals identified, these second year results may support the favorable benefit-risk profile of Evrysdi over a longer period of time.”

At this time, Evrysdi has been approved in seven countries and submitted in 57, including the EU 27 and Norway and Iceland.
